THERE IS AN ALTERNATIVE
In an editorial discussing the problem of cheating in McCoy
College, we stated two weeks ago that "proctoring is inconsistent
with the Hopkins tradtiion."
Our primary consideration at that time was the realization of
a moral threat and the need for immediate action. To some extent
this threat has been checked and the need answered.
The action taken was a request for closer supervision of tests
and examinations by the instructors. It was a precaution put into
effect without any hesitation. The Acting Dean of McCoy College
is lo he commended for the sift enactment of this temporary
measure.
We shall continue to favor the extension of the day school
honor system to the night sessions. It seems clearly unavoidable
to us that a person without the will to preserve his honor has no
place in a division of the Johns Hopkins University, regardless
of how large or how heterogeneous that division might be.
A number of formidable obsttacles stand in the way of the
establishment of an honor commission in McCoy College, the most
exasperating of which is the diffieulty of impressing on the shortterm, part-time students the importance of an honor code.
Indications show that every effort will be made both by interested day students and by the Dean to work out answers to these
various problems. Discussion will be directed toward their honor
code as the ideal goal.
Reason demands, however, that this goal not be set up as the
only acceptable solution. The essential problem, it is repeated for
emphasis, is to stamp out cheating. If the individuals whose duty
it will be to choose the better method find the obstacles to an honor
system too great to overcome, only one alternative will be left to
them.
We are confident that, inasmuch as attention has been focused
on the disturbing state Of affairs in the !light school, avoidance
of the issue will not persist. The least possible measure that can
be effected is a thorough and workable system of proctoring.

A LIBRARY REQUEST
Although the Hopkins libraries are open many hours during
every day of the- week they are not available to students on
Sundays.
Sunday afternoon and evening are spent in study by many
who have heavy curricular and extra-curricular duties permitting them few hours of concentration during the week. It is at
this time that the main reading room should be open for reference
work and as a place to "get away" from home, the dorm or the
fraternity house.
An arrangement such as this would not require more than
two student librarians on hand to supervise. Such move on the
part of the library—a few hours of study on Sunday in the main
reading room—would be welcomed by a large enough group of
students to,:warrant it.

Lengthy Bore
The longest single project in recent guinea pig history ran its
monotonous course last winter and
spring. Originally billed for some
30 hours, in two-hour stretches,
the experiment was prolonged to
about 40 when what the researcher
called "some very interesting indications" were discovered in the
early statistics.
Since this particular project
called for listening over earphoneS
to endless successions of singularly unvarying museial notes, and
noting down the variations, it
rapidly grew to the proportions of
torture. Constant fallings asleep
inside the specially-provided soundproof room were rudely interrupted by an anxious "Are you still
there?" The stock answer was a
swallowed yawn, plus "Sure. I'm
fine—uh, how about taking a rest
now?"
The Lines
But the most tiring of all the
tests was a mere three-hour stint
spent squinting through the wrong
end of a telescope at a straight
line. Across this line at changing
another
intervals was placed
straight line. The trick was to
estimate the interval—one-third
of the line, three-tenths, and so
forth. That job was such a strain
that the guinea pig was provided
with coffee to keep him awake
absolutely-free, mind you!
The experiment which came
nearest to disaster involved dartthrowing in an unlit room. After
each toss at the target, the guinea
pig was shown how much he had
missed by—the point being to see
how badly he was discouraged.
One subject got so downhearted
that he narrowly missed • the instructor. The dart quivered in the
wall behind the man's ear: shaking and pale, he called off the
session for that day and sent the
subject home.
But the.guinea pig got his 75
cents, all the same.

The two hour long, intermissionless philosophic repartee was
originally written as a fantasy
section of George Bernard Shaw'S
Man and Superman; it is the kind
of thing only Shaw could do. There
is no action, no costume, no scenery (except the out of place faded
baroque landscape left over front
the symphony concert of the night
before), and yet the play, a static
conversation between Shaw and
himselves is a most challenging,
timely (although written 50 yearS
ago) concentration of views on
Life. Death, Women, Sex, War,
Politics. Machines, Englishmen,
and other things in general.
Though the dialogue is witty, it is
most serious, only relieved by Sir
Cedric's comic relief and an imposed intermission.
Unlike Major Barbara, where
the ending tends to be contrived,
or Devil's Disciple, which merely
pokes academic fun at straightlaced conceptions, Shaw in Don
Juan gives not only a debunking
of nice notions, but also presents
a realistic and sophisticated alternative of his own. The philosophy

PREDICTIONS
Confidence, lads, and a good average from the previous
week are the prime factors in the success of a football procrastinator. And this wek the 'Nester has both. First we have
a few games that will swell our average without too much
trouble.
Maryland over Missouri: Tatum vs. Faurot, pupil vs. teacher
should make for an interesting game. Not much doubt
about the outcome.
Princeton over Brown: Just a matter of `by how much'.
over Army: The Cadets are due for a boxing itsson.
El Trojan is by far the more powerful of the two.
Penn over William and Mary:
Now the going gets rocky. Several of these games should
be called toss-tips but we'll stand by our guns and hope our luck
from last week holds out.
Illinois over Michigan: Karras and Co. took Indiana last week
but while Michigan's offense was scoring 54 points their
defense allowed lowly Minnesota to score 27 against them.
A battle of offenses.
Upset of the week: Washington State over Stanford! Last
week unbeaten Stanford looked fair against Washington, especially
in the air. But W.S.C. by downing Oregon State,' a powerful
single-wing team with a huge line, proved that they have a line that
is to be contended with. If that line can put the damper on Harry
Hugasin, the boys from the farm country will have themselves a
game.

Don Manger, Jay sophomore

Wednesday against Loyola College.
Manger literally burned up the
course in the Loyola meet as he
romped to an easy victory in the

8 seconds over the four mile plus
Homewood course. Manger's time
broke the course record by 47

THERE IS AN ALTERNATIVE
In an editorial discussing the problem of cheating in McCoy
College, we stated two weeks ago that "proctoring is inconsistent
with the Hopkins tradtiion."
Our primary consideration at that time was the realization of
a moral threat and the need for immediate action. To some extent
this threat has been checked and the need answered.
The action taken was a request for closer supervision of tests
and examinations by the instructors. It was a precaution put into
effect without any hesitation. The Acting Dean of McCoy College
is lo he commended for the sift enactment of this temporary
measure.
We shall continue to favor the extension of the day school
honor system to the night sessions. It seems clearly unavoidable
to us that a person without the will to preserve his honor has no
place in a division of the Johns Hopkins University, regardless
of how large or how heterogeneous that division might be.
A number of formidable obsttacles stand in the way of the
establishment of an honor commission in McCoy College, the most
exasperating of which is the diffieulty of impressing on the shortterm, part-time students the importance of an honor code.
Indications show that every effort will be made both by interested day students and by the Dean to work out answers to these
various problems. Discussion will be directed toward their honor
code as the ideal goal.
Reason demands, however, that this goal not be set up as the
only acceptable solution. The essential problem, it is repeated for
emphasis, is to stamp out cheating. If the individuals whose duty
it will be to choose the better method find the obstacles to an honor
system too great to overcome, only one alternative will be left to
them.
We are confident that, inasmuch as attention has been focused
on the disturbing state Of affairs in the !light school, avoidance
of the issue will not persist. The least possible measure that can
be effected is a thorough and workable system of proctoring.

A LIBRARY REQUEST
Although the Hopkins libraries are open many hours during
every day of the- week they are not available to students on
Sundays.
Sunday afternoon and evening are spent in study by many
who have heavy curricular and extra-curricular duties permitting them few hours of concentration during the week. It is at
this time that the main reading room should be open for reference
work and as a place to "get away" from home, the dorm or the
fraternity house.
An arrangement such as this would not require more than
two student librarians on hand to supervise. Such move on the
part of the library—a few hours of study on Sunday in the main
reading room—would be welcomed by a large enough group of
students to,:warrant it.

Lengthy Bore
The longest single project in recent guinea pig history ran its
monotonous course last winter and
spring. Originally billed for some
30 hours, in two-hour stretches,
the experiment was prolonged to
about 40 when what the researcher
called "some very interesting indications" were discovered in the
early statistics.
Since this particular project
called for listening over earphoneS
to endless successions of singularly unvarying museial notes, and
noting down the variations, it
rapidly grew to the proportions of
torture. Constant fallings asleep
inside the specially-provided soundproof room were rudely interrupted by an anxious "Are you still
there?" The stock answer was a
swallowed yawn, plus "Sure. I'm
fine—uh, how about taking a rest
now?"
The Lines
But the most tiring of all the
tests was a mere three-hour stint
spent squinting through the wrong
end of a telescope at a straight
line. Across this line at changing
another
intervals was placed
straight line. The trick was to
estimate the interval—one-third
of the line, three-tenths, and so
forth. That job was such a strain
that the guinea pig was provided
with coffee to keep him awake
absolutely-free, mind you!
The experiment which came
nearest to disaster involved dartthrowing in an unlit room. After
each toss at the target, the guinea
pig was shown how much he had
missed by—the point being to see
how badly he was discouraged.
One subject got so downhearted
that he narrowly missed • the instructor. The dart quivered in the
wall behind the man's ear: shaking and pale, he called off the
session for that day and sent the
subject home.
But the.guinea pig got his 75
cents, all the same.

PREDICTIONS
Confidence, lads, and a good average from the previous
week are the prime factors in the success of a football procrastinator. And this wek the 'Nester has both. First we have
a few games that will swell our average without too much
trouble.
Maryland over Missouri: Tatum vs. Faurot, pupil vs. teacher
should make for an interesting game. Not much doubt
about the outcome.
Princeton over Brown: Just a matter of `by how much'.
over Army: The Cadets are due for a boxing itsson.
El Trojan is by far the more powerful of the two.
Penn over William and Mary:
Now the going gets rocky. Several of these games should
be called toss-tips but we'll stand by our guns and hope our luck
from last week holds out.
Illinois over Michigan: Karras and Co. took Indiana last week
but while Michigan's offense was scoring 54 points their
defense allowed lowly Minnesota to score 27 against them.
A battle of offenses.
Upset of the week: Washington State over Stanford! Last
week unbeaten Stanford looked fair against Washington, especially
in the air. But W.S.C. by downing Oregon State,' a powerful
single-wing team with a huge line, proved that they have a line that
is to be contended with. If that line can put the damper on Harry
Hugasin, the boys from the farm country will have themselves a
game.

Manger Runs
Harrier Race
For Record

Don Manger, Jay sophomore
sensation, continued his terrific
running as he led the Hopkins harriers to their third triumph of the
season against two defeats last
Wednesday against Loyola College.
Manger literally burned up the
course in the Loyola meet as he
romped to an easy victory in the
spectacular time of 21 minutes and
8 seconds over the four mile plus
Homewood course. Manger's time
broke the course record by 47
seconds. He had set the mark
just eleven days previous.
Ed Colburn paced the Loyola
squad, which was undefeated up
until the Jays met them, with a
Colburn's

Gallo of the homesters for fourth
place by just two seconds. Gallo,
who has been off and on this
season, seemed to be on for this
meet and was timed in 22.57 for
fifth place.
Stone Good
Tom Stone, continuing his good
running, completed the course in
23:22 to gain sixth place in the
race. Dick Martin, running his
first varsity race, ran a very good
race and edged out Andy John,
another
Jay
sophomore, for
seventh place in the race. George
Kirnmerline followed this quartet
of Jay runners over the finish line
with a ninth place finish.
Thigh Logan and John Wotell
tied for tenth, Bud Howard placed
thirteenth, and Hans Ottle sixteenth to complete the finishers for
the Jays. Ball and DeSantis completed the Loyola scoring by placing 12th and 14th.
